A galaxy's magnetic field influences its dynamics in multiple ways, including affecting the [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation) of [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) arms and transporting angular momentum in gas clouds. The latter effect is particularly important, as it is a necessary factor for the [gravitational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitation) collapse of those clouds, and thus for [star [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_formation). The typical average [equipartition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equipartition_theorem) strength for [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxies is about 10 μG ([microgauss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauss_(unit))) or 1 nT ([nanotesla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla_(unit))). By comparison, the Earth's magnetic field has an average strength of about 0.3 G (Gauss) or 30 μT ([microtesla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla_(unit))). [Radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_galaxy)-faint galaxies like [M 31](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) and [M33](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangulum_Galaxy), the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way)'s neighbors, have weaker fields (about 5 μG), while gas-rich galaxies with high star-[formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation) rates, like M 51, M 83 and NGC 6946, have 15 μG on average. In prominent [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) arms, the field strength can be up to 25 μG, in regions where cold gas and [dust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmic_dust) are also concentrated. The strongest total [equipartition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equipartition_theorem) fields (50–100 μG) were found in [[starburst](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starburst_(astronomy)) galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starburst_galaxy)—for example, in M 82 and the [Antennae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antennae_Galaxies); and in nuclear [starburst](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starburst_(astronomy)) regions, such as the centers of NGC 1097 and other [[barred](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barred_irregular_galaxy) galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barred_spiral_galaxy).

Current models of the [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation) of galaxies in the early [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe) are based on the [ΛCDM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lambda-CDM_model) model. About 300,000 years after the [Big Bang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Bang), atoms of [hydrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen) and [helium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helium) began to form, in an event called [recombination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recombination_(cosmology)). Nearly all the [hydrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen) was neutral (non-[ionized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ion)) and readily absorbed light, and no [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) had yet formed. As a result, this period has been called the "[dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_galaxy) ages". It was from density fluctuations (or [anisotropic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anisotropy) irregularities) in this primordial matter that [larger structures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structure_formation) began to appear. As a result, masses of [baryonic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baryon) matter started to condense within cold [[dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_galaxy) matter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter) halos. These primordial structures allowed gasses to condense in to [protogalaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Protogalaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protogalaxy)), large scale gas clouds that were precursors to the first galaxies.: 6  As gas falls in to the [gravity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravity) of the [[dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_galaxy) matter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter) halos, its pressure and temperature rise. To condense further, the gas must radiate energy. This process was slow in the early [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe) dominated by [hydrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen) atoms and molecules which are inefficient radiators compared to heavier elements. As clumps of gas aggregate forming rotating disks, temperatures and pressures continue to increase. Some places within the disk reach high enough density to form [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star).  Once [protogalaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Protogalaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protogalaxy)) began to form and contract, the first halo [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), called Population III [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), appeared within them. These were composed of primordial gas, almost entirely of [hydrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen) and [helium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helium). Emission from the first [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) heats the remaining gas helping to trigger additional [star [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_formation); the ultraviolet light emission from the first generation of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) re-[ionized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ion) the surrounding neutral [hydrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen) in expanding spheres eventually reaching the entire [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe), an event called [reionization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reionization). The most massive [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) collapse in violent [supernova](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supernova) explosions releasing heavy elements ("metals") into the [interstellar medium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstellar_medium).: 14  This metal content is incorporated into population II [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star). Theoretical models for early galaxy [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation) have been verified and informed by a large number and variety of sophisticated astronomical observations.: 43  The photometric observations generally need spectroscopic confirmation due the large number mechanisms that can introduce systematic errors. For example, a high redshift (z ~ 16) photometric observation by [James Webb Space Telescope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Webb_Space_Telescope) (JWST) was later corrected to be closer to z ~ 5. Nevertheless, confirmed observations from the JWST and other observatories are accumulating, allowing systematic comparison of early galaxies to predictions of theory. Evidence for individual Population III [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) in early galaxies is even more challenging. Even seemingly confirmed spectroscopic evidence may turn out to have other origins. For example, astronomers reported HeII emission evidence for Population III [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) in the [Cosmos Redshift 7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmos_Redshift_7) galaxy, with a redshift value of 6.60. Subsequent observations found metallic emission lines, OIII, inconsistent with an early-galaxy star.: 108

Once [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) begin to form, emit radiation, and in some cases explode, the process of galaxy [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation) becomes very complex, involving interactions between the forces of [gravity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravity), radiation, and thermal energy. Many details are still poorly understood. Within a billion years of a galaxy's [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation), key structures begin to appear. Globular [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies), the central [supermassive black hole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole), and a galactic [bulge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulge_(astronomy)) of metal-poor Population II [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) form. The creation of a [supermassive black hole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole) appears to play a key role in actively regulating the growth of galaxies by limiting the total amount of additional matter added. During this early epoch, galaxies undergo a major burst of [star [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_formation). During the following two billion years, the accumulated matter settles into a [galactic disc](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disc_(galaxy)). A galaxy will continue to absorb infalling material from [high-velocity clouds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-velocity_cloud) and [dwarf galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_galaxy) throughout its life. This matter is mostly [hydrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen) and [helium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helium). The cycle of stellar birth and death slowly increases the abundance of heavy elements, eventually allowing the [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation) of [planets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planet).  Star [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation) rates in galaxies depend upon their local environment. Isolated 'void' galaxies have highest rate per stellar mass, with 'field' galaxies associated with [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxies having lower rates and galaxies in dense [cluster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galaxy_cluster) having the lowest rates. The evolution of galaxies can be significantly affected by interactions and collisions. Mergers of galaxies were common during the early epoch, and the majority of galaxies were peculiar in [morphology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphology_(astronomy)). Given the distances between the [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), the great majority of stellar [systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_system) in colliding galaxies will be unaffected. However, [gravitational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitation) stripping of the [interstellar gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstellar_medium) and [dust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmic_dust) that makes up the [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) arms produces a long train of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) known as tidal tails. Examples of these formations can be seen in [NGC 4676](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NGC_4676) or the [[Antennae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antennae_Galaxies) [Galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Category](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Galaxies):Galaxies)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antennae_Galaxies). The [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) galaxy and the nearby [[Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) are moving toward each other at about 130 [km/s](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metre_per_second), and—depending upon the lateral movements—the two might collide in about five to six billion years. Although the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) has never collided with a galaxy as large as [Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) before, it has collided and merged with other galaxies in the past. Cosmological simulations indicate that, 11 billion years ago, it merged with a particularly large galaxy that has been labeled the [Kraken](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kraken_galaxy). Such large-scale interactions are rare. As time passes, mergers of two [systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_system) of equal size become less common. Most bright galaxies have remained fundamentally unchanged for the last few billion years, and the net rate of [star [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_formation) probably also peaked about ten billion years ago.

[Spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_spiral_galaxies) galaxies, like the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way), produce new generations of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) as long as they have dense [molecular clouds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecular_cloud) of interstellar [hydrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen) in their [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) arms. Elliptical galaxies are largely devoid of this gas, and so form few new [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star). The supply of star-forming material is finite; once [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) have converted the available supply of [hydrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen) into heavier elements, new [star [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_formation) will come to an end. The current era of [star [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_formation) is expected to continue for up to one hundred billion years, and then the "stellar age" will wind down after about ten [trillion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/10%5E12) to one hundred [trillion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/10%5E12) years (1013–1014 years), as the smallest, longest-lived [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) in the visible [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe), tiny red [dwarfs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_galaxy), begin to fade. At the end of the stellar age, galaxies will be composed of [compact objects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compact_star): brown [dwarfs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_galaxy), white [dwarfs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_galaxy) that are cooling or cold ("black [dwarfs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_galaxy)"), neutron [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), and [black holes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_hole). Eventually, as a result of [gravitational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitation) relaxation, all [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) will either fall into central supermassive [black holes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_hole) or be flung into intergalactic space as a result of collisions.
